commander.name: Major-General Arthur Allen
commander.previous_service: Replaced Major-General John Lavarack who was promoted to command Australian I Corps

command.headquarters_location: Palestine/Syria (Division HQ) - 18th Brigade detached to Tobruk, Libya
command.note: Division HQ and two brigades (21st, 25th) were in Syria-Lebanon (outside North Africa scope). Only 18th Brigade was in North Africa at Tobruk.

tanks.note: 18th Brigade was infantry brigade - no organic tank units. Tank support at Tobruk provided by attached British armoured units.

halftracks.note: Halftracks not in Australian service in 1941-Q3

field_artillery.note: No brigade-level field artillery. Fire support provided by Tobruk Garrison artillery units.

Vickers .303in Medium MG.note: Battalion support platoons - 6 per battalion (3 battalions)

Bren Gun.note: Additional Bren guns beyond section allocation for fire support

reconnaissance.note: Air support provided by RAF Middle East Command

supply_logistics.supply_status: Besieged - supplied by sea from Alexandria (360km). Nightly destroyer and coastal vessel runs ('Spud Run'). Critical constraints: limited port capacity, enemy air/naval interdiction. Water strictly rationed. Ammunition adequate for defensive operations.

weather_environment.terrain_type: coastal desert - defensive perimeter around Tobruk port (30km perimeter)

subordinate_units.note: Brigade detached from 7th Division to Tobruk garrison April-August 1941. Relieved by Polish brigade and evacuated by sea in August. Rejoined division in Syria September 1941.

source: Australian War Memorial - Siege of Tobruk articles (web)
The Rommel Papers - Tobruk siege narrative

chief_of_staff.name.reason: Division HQ staff records not available for period when only one brigade was in North Africa
chief_of_staff.name.mitigation: Consult Australian National Archives Series B3856 for divisional staff appointments

precise_headquarters_location.reason: Division HQ was in Syria-Lebanon area (outside North Africa scope) with only 18th Brigade at Tobruk
precise_headquarters_location.mitigation: Location is known as Syria-Lebanon, but 18th Brigade operational control was under Tobruk Garrison commander

primary_sources: Australian War Memorial - Siege of Tobruk articles (web)
The Rommel Papers - Tobruk siege narrative
data_gaps: Chief of Staff name and details
Exact operational readiness percentages for vehicles
notes: SCOPE LIMITATION: Only 18th Brigade was in North Africa (Tobruk) during 1941-Q3
21st and 25th Brigades remained in Syria-Lebanon (outside project scope)
Division HQ was in Syria-Lebanon, not North Africa
18th Brigade operationally controlled by Tobruk Garrison commander (Lt. Gen. Morshead)
Brigade evacuated from Tobruk by sea in August 1941 (5,040 men evacuated)
Brigade rejoined division in Syria in September 1941
Personnel and equipment counts reflect single brigade strength only
Tobruk siege: 10 April - 27 November 1941, 18th Brigade present May-August
Supply by sea ('Spud Run') nightly destroyer and coastal vessel runs from Alexandria
Water strictly rationed due to limited storage and production capacity in Tobruk
Australian garrison earned nickname 'Rats of Tobruk' from German propaganda

historical_context.operational_status: Defensive siege operations - Tobruk Garrison (18th Brigade only)
historical_context.opponents: German Afrika Korps and Italian forces under General Erwin Rommel
major_battles: Easter Battle (14-17 April 1941) - before 18th Brigade arrival
historical_context.outcomes: 18th Brigade successfully defended Tobruk sector May-August 1941. Evacuated by sea in August, rejoined division in Syria September 1941.

casualties_1941q3.killed: Unknown - specific Q3 figures not available
casualties_1941q3.wounded: Unknown - specific Q3 figures not available
casualties_1941q3.note: Total Tobruk garrison casualties April-November 1941: 832 KIA, 2,177 WIA, 941 POW (includes all nationalities)

special_notes: Unique situation: Division represented by single brigade at Tobruk
18th Brigade under operational control of Tobruk Garrison commander (Lt. Gen. Leslie Morshead, 9th Australian Division)
Brigade evacuated by Royal Navy in August 1941 as part of garrison rotation
5,040 men of 18th Brigade and Indian 18th Cavalry evacuated by sea
Siege supply by 'Spud Run' - nightly destroyer/coastal vessel runs from Alexandria (360km)
Germans called Australian defenders 'Rats of Tobruk' - badge of honor
Tobruk's 30km defensive perimeter held by ~25,000 men (peak strength)
Water rationed to 3 liters/person/day due to limited production/storage
Brigade faced extreme heat (38Â°C+) and limited cover in desert positions
